titleStmt.title: The araygnement of Paris a pastorall. Presented before the Queenes Maiestie, by the Children of her chappell.
Giudito di Paride.
titleStmt.author: Peele, George, 1556-1596.
Paulilli, Anello.

note.p: Possibly based on: Paulilli, Anello. Il giudito di Paride.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

div.p: The Araygnement of Paris A PASTORALL. Presented before the Queenes Maiestie, by the Children of her Chappell.
Imprinted at London by Henrie Marsh. ANNO. 1584.

div.head: Ate Prologus.
div.l: COndemned soule Ate, from lowest hell,
And deadlie riuers of the infernall loue,
Where bloudles ghostes in paines of endles date
Fill ruthles eares with neuer ceasing cries,
Beholde I come in place, and bring beside
The bane of Troie: beholde the fatall frute
Raught from the golden tree of Proserpine.
Proude Troy must fall, so bidde the gods aboue,
And statelie Iliums loftie towers be racet
By conquering handes of the victorious foe:
King Priams pallace waste with flaming fire,
Whose thicke and foggie smoake peircing the skie,
Must serue for messenger of sacrifice
Tappeaze the anger of the angrie heauens,
And Priams younger sonne, the sheepeherde swaine,
Paris th'unhappie organ of the Greekes.
So loath and weerie of her heauie loade
The Earth complaynes vnto the hellish prince,
Surcharged with the burden that she nill sustaine.
Th'unpartiall daughters of Necessitie
Bin aydes in her sute: and so the twine
That holdes olde Priams house, the threede of Troie
Dame Atrops with knife in sunder cuttes.
Done be the pleasure of the powers aboue,
Whose hestes men must obey: and I my parte
Performe in Ida vales: Lordinges adieu,
Imposing silence for your taske, I ende,
Till iust assemblie of the goddesses
Make me beginne the Tragedie of Troie.
div.stage: Exit Ate 〈…〉.

div.head: SCENA. I.
div.stage: Pan, Faunus, and Siluanus with their attendants enter to giue welcome to the goddesses: Pans sheepeherd hath a lambe, Faunus hunter hath a faune, Siluanus woodman with an oken bowe laden with acornes.
Pan incipit.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: SILVANUS, 〈…〉
For by this morning mirth to shoulde appeare
The 〈◊〉 or the goddesses be neer

sp.speaker: Faun.
sp.l: My 〈◊〉 was nimble, Pan, and whipt apace
Twas 〈◊〉 that he caught him vp at last.
The fattest fairest faune 〈…〉
the chace I wonder how 〈…〉 so fast.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And I haue brought a twagger for the nonce
A bunting lambe: nay, pray you feele no bones.
Beleeue me now, my cunning much I misse,
If euer Pan 〈…〉 then this.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Sirs, you may boast your flockes & herdes that bin both fresh & faire,
Yet hath Siluanus walkes ywis that stand in holsome ayre.
And loe the honor of the woodes, the gallant Oken-bowe,
Do I bestowe laden with Acornes & with mast enough.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Peace man for shame, shalt haue both lambes & dames & flockes and herdes & al,
And all my pipes to make the glee, we meete not now to brawle.

sp.speaker: Faun.
sp.l: Theres no such matter, Pan▪ we are all friendes assembled hether,
To bid Queene Iuno and her pheeres most humblie welcome hether.
Diana mistresse of our woodes, her presence will not want,
Her curtesie to all her friendes we wot is nothing skant.

div.head: ACT. I.
SCENA. II.
div.stage: Pomona entereth with her fruite. Manentibus Pan cum reliquis.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Yee Par, no farther yet, & had the starte of me,
Why then Pomona wit her fruite comes time enough I see:
Come on a while, with countrie store like friendes we vente- forth,
Thinkest Faunus that these goddesses will take our giftes in woorth.

sp.speaker: Faun.
sp.l: Yea doubtles, for shall tell thee dame, twere better giue a thing,
A signe of loue, vnto a mightie person, or a king:
Then to a rude and barbarous swayne 〈…〉 borne,
For gentlie takes the 〈…〉 the clowne will scorne.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Saist trulie Faunus, I my selfe haue giuen good ridie lambes,
To Mercurie may saie to thee, to Phoebus and to Loue:
When to a countrie mops forsooth, chace offred all their dames,
And pypt and prayed for little worth and raunged about the groue.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: God Pan that makes your flocke so thin, & makes you looke so leane,
To kisse in corners. Pan. wel-sed wench some other thing you meane.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Yea rest it out till it goe alone, but maruell where we mylle
Faire Flora all this merrie morne. Faun. some newes see where she is.

div.head: ACT. I.
SCENA. III.
div.stage: Flora entereth to the countrie gods.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Flora well met, and for thy taken payne,
Poore countrie gods thy debters we remaine.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Beleeue me, Pan, not all thy lambes and yoes,
Nor, Faunus, all thy lustie buckes and does,
(But that I am instructed well to knowe,
What seruice to the hills and dales I owe,)
Could haue enforcet one to so straunge a toyle,
Thus to enrich this gaudie gallant soyle.

sp.speaker: Faun.
sp.l: But tell me wench hast don't so trick in deede,
That heauen it selfe may wonder at the deede.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: Not Iris in her pride and brauerie,
Adornes her arche with such varietie:
Nor doth the milke white way in frostie night,
Appeare so faire and beautifull in sight:
As done these fieldes, and groues, and sweetest bowres,
Bestrewed and deckt with partie collord flowers.
Alonge the bubling brookes & siluer glyde,
that at the bottome doth in sylence slyde,
The waterie flowers and lillies on the bankes,
Like blazing cometes burgen all in rankes:
Vnder the Hathorne and the Poplar tree,
Where sacred Phoebe may delight to be:
The Primerose and the purple Hyacinthe,
The dayntie Violet 〈…〉 Minthe.
The dooble Daisie, and the Coweslip queene
Of sommer floures do ouer peere the greene:
And rounde about the valley as ye passe,
Yee may ne see for peeping flowers the grasse:
That well the mightie Ioue and the rest,
May boldlie thinke to be a welcome guest
On Ida hills, when to approue the thing,
The queene of flowers prepares a second spring.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Thou gentle Nymphe, what thankes shall we repaie
To thee, that makest our fieldes and woodes so gaie?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Siluanus, when it is thy hap to see,
My workemanship, in portraying all the three,
First stately Iuno with her porte and grace,
Her roobes, her lawnes, her crounet and her mace:
Would make thee muse this picture to beholde,
Of yellow Oxstips bright as burnisht golde.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: A rare deuice, and Flora, well perdie,
Did painte her yellow for her iellozie.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Pallas in flowers of hue and collowers red,
Her plumes, her helme, her launce, her Gorgons head,
Her trayling tresses that hang flaring rounde,
Of Iulie-flowers so graffed in the grounde,
That trust me Sirs, who did the cunning see,
Would at a blush suppose it to be shee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Good Flora, by my flocke twere verie good,
To dight her all in red resembling blood.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Faire Venus of sweete Violetts in blue.
With other flowers infixt for chaunge of hue,
Her plumes, her pendants, bracelets and her ringes,
Her dayntie fan and twentie other thinges:
Her lustie mantle wauing in the winde,
And euerie part in collor and in kinde:
And for her wreath of roses she nil dare,
With Floras cunning counterfet compare.
So that what lyuing whight shall chaunce to see,
These goddesses, eche placed in her degree,
Portrayed by Floraes workemanshipe alone,
Must say that Arte and nature met in one.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: A deintie draught to lay her downe in blue,
The collour commonlie betokening true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This peece of worke compact with many a flowre,
And well layde in at entraunce of the bowre,
Where Phoebe meanes to make this meeting royall.
Haue I prepared to welcome them withall.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: And are they yet dismounted, Flora, saie:
That we may wende to meete them one the way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That shall not neede: they are at hand by this,
And the conductor of the trayne hight Rhanis.
Iuno hath left her chariot longe agoe,
And hath returned her Peacocks by her rainebow.
And brauelie as becommes the wife of Ioue,
Doth honour by her presence to our groue.
Faire Venus shee hath let her sparrowes flie,
To tende on her and make her melodie:
Her turtles and her swannes vnyoked bee,
And flicker neere her side for companie.
Pallas hath set her Tygers loose to feede,
Commaunding them to waite when shee hath neede.
And Hitherward with proude and statelie pace,
To doe vs honor in the Siluan chace
They marche like to the pompe of heauen aboue,
Iuno the wife and sister of king Ioue,
The warlicke Pallas, and the Queene of loue.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Pipe Pan for ioy and let thy sheepeherdes sing,
Shall neuer age forget this memorable thing.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Clio the sagest of the sisters nine,
To do obseruaunce to this dame deuine,
Il ad●e of learning and of chyualrie,
Is here aryued in faire assemblie,
And wandring vp and downe th'unbeaten wayes,
Ringe through the wood sweete songes of Pallas prayse.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: Harke Flora, Faunus, here is melodie,
A charme of birdes and more then ordinarie.

div.stage: An artificiall charme of birdes being harde within, Pan speakes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The sillie birdes make mirth, then shoulde we doe them wronge,
Pomona, if we nil bestowe an Eccho to their songe.

div.stage: An Eccho to their song.
The song 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Gods.
sp.l: O Ida, o Ida; 〈…〉
This honour done to Ida may it continue still.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Yee countrie gods,
Bring downe your giftes of welcome:
For honor done to Ida.

sp.speaker: Gods.
sp.l: Beholde in signe of 〈…〉
And signes of ioyfull wel come bring.
For honor done to Ida.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The Muses giue you melodie to gratulate this chaunce,
And Phoebe cheife of siluan chace commaundes you all to daunce.

sp.speaker: Gods
sp.l: The rounde in a circle our sportance must be,

sp.speaker: daunce.
sp.l: Holde handes in a hornepype all gallant in glee.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Reuerence, reuerence, most humble reuerence.

sp.speaker: Gods.
sp.l: Most humble reuerence.

div.head: ACT. I.
SCENA. IIII.
div.stage: Pallas, Iuno, and Venus 〈…〉

lg.head: The songe.
lg.l: The God of sheepeheardes and his mates,
With countrie chere salutes your states▪
Faire, wise, and worthie as you bee,
And thanke the gracious Ladies three,
For honour done to Ida. The birdes singe.

div.stage: The songe being done, Iuno speakes.

sp.speaker: Iuno.
sp.l: Venus, what shall I saie, for though I be a dame deuine,
This welcome and this melodie exceedes these wittes of mine.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Beleeue me, Iuno, as I hight thee soueraigne of Loue,
These rare delightes in pleasures passe the banquets of king Ioue.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Then, Venus, I conclude, it easelie may be seene,
That in her chaste and pleasaunt walkes fayre Phoebe is a Queene.

sp.speaker: Rha.
sp.l: Diuine Pallas, and you sacred dames,
Iuno and Venus, honoured by your names:
Iuno, the wife and sister of kinge Ioue,
Faire Venus, Ladie president of loue:
If any entertaynment in this place,
That can afford but homely, rude and base,
It pleaze your godheads to accept in gree,
That gratious thought our happinesse shalbe.
My mistresse Dian, this right well I know,
For loue that to this presence shee doth owe,
Accountes more honoure done to her this day,
Then euer whilom in these woods of Ida.
And for our countrey gods, I dare bee bolde,
They make such cheere, your presence to beholde,
Such iouysaunce, such myrth and merry ment,
As nothing els their minde might more content:
And that you doe beleeue it to bee so,
Fayre goddesses, your louely lookes doe showe.
It rests in fine, for to confirme my talke,
Yee dayne to passe alonge to Dians walke:
Where shee amonge her troupe of maydes attends.
The fayre aryuall of her welcome friends.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.l: And wee will wayte with all obseruance due,
And doe iust honour to this heauenly crue.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The god of sheepheardes, Iuno, ere thou goe,
Intends a lambe on thee for to bestowe.

sp.speaker: Faun.
sp.l: Faunus, high raunger in Dianas chace,
Presents a fawne to lady Venus grace.

sp.speaker: Sylu.
sp.l: Syluanus giues to Pallas deitye,
This gallant bowe raught from the Oken tree.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: To them that doth this honour to our fieldes,
Her mellowe apples poore Pomona yeildes.

sp.speaker: Iuno.
sp.l: And gentle gods, these signes of your goodwill
Wee take in worth, and shall accept them still.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And Flora, this to thee amonge the rest,
Thy workmanship comparinge with the best,
Let it suffize thy cunninge to haue,
To call kinge Ioue from forth his heauenly bowre:
Hadst thou a louer, Flora, credit mee,
I thinke thou wouldst beedecke him gallantly.
But wende we on, and, Rhanis, leade the way,
That kens the paynted pathes of pleasunt Ida.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes.

div.head: ACT. I
SCENA▪ V.
div.stage: Paris and Oenone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oenone, while we bin disposed to walke,
Tell me what shall be subiect of oure talke
Thou hast a sorte of 〈…〉
Dare saye no Nymphe in Ida woods hath more
Againe, beside thy sweete alluring face
In telling them thou hast a speciall grace
Then preethee sweete, afforde some pretie thing,
Some toie that from thy pleasaunt witte doth springe.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Paris, my hartes contentment, and my choice,
Vse thou thy pype, and I will vse my voyce,
So shall thy iust request not be denyed.
And time well spent and 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Well gentle Nymphe although thou do me wrong,
That can ne tune pype vnto a songe,
Me list this once, Oenone〈…〉, for〈…〉 thy sake,
This idle talke 〈…〉.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: And whereon then shall be my Roundelay:
For thou hast harde my stoore long since, dare say,

sp.speaker: Fabula.
sp.l: How Saturne did deuide his kingdome tho,
To Ioue, to Neptune, and to Dis below.
How mightie men made foole,
Against the gods and state of Iupiter:
How Phorcias ympe that was for ricke and fayre;
That tangled Neptune in her golden haire,
Became a Gorgon for her lewde misdeede,
A pretie fable Paris for to reade.
A peece of cunnig trust me for the nonce,
That wealth and beautie alter men to stoones.
Howe Salmacis resembling ydlenes,
Turnes men to women all through wantonnes.
How Pluto raught Queene Ceres daughter thence,
And what did followe of that loue offence.
Of Daphne turned into the laurell tree,
That shewes a myror of virginitie.
How faire Narcissus tooting on his shade,
Reproues disdayne, and 〈…〉.
How cunning Philomelaes needle tells,
What force in loue, what wit in sorrow dwelles.
What paynes vnhappie soules abyde in hell,
They say because on earth they liued not well.
Ixions wheele, proude Tantals payning woe.
Prometheus torment, and a many moe.
How Danaus daughters plie their endles taske.
What toyle the toyle of Sysiphus doth aske.
All these are olde and knowne I knowe, yet if thou wilt haue anie,
Chuse some of these, for trust me else Oenone hath not manie.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nay what thou wilt: but sith my cunning not compares with thine,
Beginne some Toy, that I can play vpon this pipe of mine.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: There is a pretie sonnet then, we call it Cupids curse:
They that do chaunge olde loue for new, pray gods they chaunge for worse.
The note is fine and quicke withall, the 〈◊〉 will agree,
Paris, With that same vowe of thine vpon our Poplar tree:

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No better thing, begine it then, Oenone thou shalt see
Our musicke, figure of the loue that growes twixt thee and me.

div.stage:
They sing: and
Incipit Oenone.
Faire and fayre and twise so faire,
As fayre as any may be:
Oenone.
The fayrest sheepeherd on our grene,
A loue for anie Ladie.
Paris.
Faire and faire and twise so fayre,
As fayre as anie may bee:
Thy loue is fayre for thee alone,
And for no other Ladie.
Oenone.
My loue is faire, my loue is gaie,
As fresh as bine the flowers in May,
And of my loue my roundylaye,
My merrie merrie merrie roundelaie
Concludes with Cupids curse:
They that do chaunge olde loue for newe,
Pray Gods they chaunge for worse.
Ambo simul.
They that do chaunge, &c.
Oenone.
Faire and faire, &c,
Paris.
Faire and faire, &c. Thy loue is faire &c.
Oenone.
My loue can pype, my loue can sing,
My loue can manie a pretie thing,
And of his louelie prayses ring
My merry merry roundelayes: Amen to Cupids curse:
They that do chaunge, &c.
Paris.
They that do chaunge, &c.
Ambo.
Faire and fayre, &c.
Finis Camaene .
while 〈◊〉 singeth▪ he pypeth.
The songe being ended they rise, and Oenone speakes.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Swete shepeherd, for Oenones sake be cunning in this songe,
And kepe thy loue, and loue thy choice, or else thou doest her wrong.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My vowe is made and witnessed, the Poplar will not starte,
Nor shall the nymphe Oenones loue from forth my breathing hart.
I will goe bring the one thy way, my flocke are here behinde,
And I will haue a louers fee: they saie, vnkist, vnkinde.

div.stage: Exeunt ambo.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Venus, Iuno, Pallas.

sp.speaker: Ven. ex abrupto.
sp.l: But pray you tell me, Iuno, was it so,
As Pallas tolde me here the tale of Eccho.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Shee was a nympe indeede, as Pallas tels,
A walker, such as in these thickets dwelle:
And as shee tolde what subtill iugling prankes
Shee playde with Iuno, so she tolde her thanks:
A tatling trull to come at euerie call,
And now foresooth nor tongue nor life at all.
And though perhaps shee was a helpe to Ioue,
And held me chat, while he might court his loue▪
Beleeue me, dames, I am of this opinion,
He tooke but little pleasure in the minion.
And what so ere his scapes haue bene beside,
Dare saie for him a neuer strayed so wyde:
A louely nutbrowne lasse, or lustie trull,
Haue power perhaps to make a god a bull.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Gramercie gentle Iuno for that iest,
I faith that item was worth all the rest.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No matter, Venus, how so ere you skorne,
My father Ioue at that time ware the horne.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Had euerie wanton god aboue, Venus, not better lucke,
Then heauen would be a pleasaunt parcke, & Mars a lustie bucke.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Tut Mars hath hornes to butte withall although no bull a showes.
A neuer needes to maske in nets, a feares no iellous froes.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Forsooth the better is his turne, for if a speake to loude,
Must finde some shifte to shadowe him, a net, or else a cloude.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No more of this, fayre goddesses, vnrip not so your shames,
To stand all naked to the world, that bene such heauenly dames.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Nay, Pallas, that's a common tricke with Venus well we knowe,
And all the Gods in heauen haue seene her naked, long agoe.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And then she was so faire and bright, and louelie and so trim,
As Mars is but for Venus tooth, and shee will sporte with him.
And but me list not here to make comparison with Ioue,
Mars is no raunger, Iuno, he in euerie open groue.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: To much of this: we wander farre, the skies begine to skowle,
Retire we to Dianas bowre, the weather will be foule.

div.stage: The storme being past of thunder & lightning, & Ate hauing trundled the ball into place▪ crying Fatum Troie, Iuno taketh the bal vp & speaketh.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Pallas, the storme is past and gon, and Phoebus cleares the skies,
And loe, beholde a ball of golde, a faire and worthie prize.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: This posie wils, the apple to the fayrest giuen be,
Then is it mine: for Venus hight the fayrest of the three.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: The fayrest here as fayre is ment, am I, ye do me wronge:
And if the fayrest haue it must, to me it doth belong

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Then Iuno may it not enioy, so euery one sayes no,
But I will proue my selfe the fayrest, er I lose it so.
The breyfe is this, 〈…〉.
Let this vnto the fayrest gyven tree,
The fayrest of the three, and I am shee.
Detur
The fayrest 〈…〉.
Detur Pulcherrima.〈 〈…〉
The fayrest of the thre, and I am shee.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: My face is fayre, 〈…〉
That all the gods in heauen 〈…〉,
Haue made them chuse me of the 〈◊〉,
To bee the wyfe of Ioue, and Queene of heauen.
Yf then this prize be 〈…〉 to beautye,
The only shee that wins this prize am I.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: That Venus is the fayrest▪ this dothe proue,
That Venus is the louely Queen of loue.
The name of Venus is in deede but bautye,
And men me fayrest call, per excellencye.
Yf then this prize be but bequeathed to beautye,
The only shee that wins this prize, am I.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: To stand on tearmes of beautye as yow take it,
Beeleue me, Ladies, is but to mystake it:
The beautye that this subtill prize must win,
No outwarde beautye highte, but dwels within.
And syfte it as yow please, and yow shall finde,
This beautye, is the beautye of the minde.
This fayrenes, Vertue highte, in generall,
That many braunches hathe in speciall:
This beauty wysdom hight, whereof am I,
By heauen appointed, goddesse worthelye.
And looke how muche the minde, the better parte,
Doth ouerpasse the bodye in deserte:
So much the mistris of those guyfts devine,
Excells thy beautie, and that state of thine.
Then yf this prize bee thus bequeathed to beautye,
The only she that wins this prize, am I.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Nay, Pallas, by your leaue, yow wander cleane,
Wee must not conster heereof as yow meane:
But take the sense as it is plainly ment,
And let the fayrest hate, I am content.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Our reasons will be infinite, I trowe,
Vnles vnto some other point we grow.
For first here's none mee thinkes disposed to yeelde,
And none but will with wordes maintaine the fielde.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Then if you will to auoyde a tedious grudge,
Refer it to the sentence of iudge,
Who ere he be that commeth next in place,
Let him bestowe the ball, and ende the case.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: So can it not go wronge with me not at al.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I am agreed how euer it befall.
And yet by common doome, so may it bee,
I may be sayde the fayrest of the three.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Then yonder loe that sheepeherde swaine is he,
That must be vmpier in this controuersie.

div.head: ACT. II.
SCENA II.
div.stage: Paris alone. Manentibus Pal. Iunone, Venere.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Iuno, in happie time, I do accept the man,
It seemeth by his lookes, some skill of loue he can.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The nymphe is gone, and I all solitarie,
Must wend to tend my charge, opprest with melancholy.
This day (or else me fayles my sheepeherdes skill)
Will tide me passing good, or passing ill.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Sheepeherd, abash not, though, at sudden thus,
Thou be aryued by ignorance among vs,
Not earthlie but deuine, and goddesses all three,
Iuno, Pallas, Venus, these our titles be.
Nor feare to speake, for reuerence of the place,
Chosen to ende a harde and doubtfull case.
This apple loe (nor aske thou whence it came)
Is to be giuen vnto the fayrest dame.
And fayrest is, nor shee, nor shee, but shee,
Whom, sheepeherd, thou shalt fayrest name to be.
This is thy charge, fulfill without offence,
And shee that winnes shall giue thee recompence.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Dreade not to speake for we haue chosen thee,
Sith in this case, we can no iudges be.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And, sheepeherd, say that I the fayrest ame,
And thou shalt win good guerdon for the same.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Nay, shepherde, looke vppon my stately grace,
Because the pompe that longs to 〈…〉
They mayst not see; and thincke Queene junoes name,
To whome olde shepherds title workes of fame,
Is mightye, and may easily suffize,
At Phebus hande to game a golden prize.
And for thy meede, sythe I ame Queene of riches,
Shepherde, I will rewarde thee with greate monarchies,
Empires, and kingdomes, heapes of massye golde,
Scepters and diadems, curious to beholde,
Riche robes, of sumpteous workmanship and cost,
And thowsand thinges whereof I make no boast
The moulde whereon thowe treadest shall be of Tagus sandes,
And Xanthus shall runne liquid golde for the to wash thy handes:
And yf thou lyke to tend thy flock, and not from them to she,
Their fleeces shalbe curled gold to please their masters eye.
And last, to sett thy harte one fire, gyue this one fruite to me,
And, shepherd, lo this Tree of Golde will I bestowe on thee.
sp.stage: Heereuppon did rise a Tree of gold laden with Diadems & Crownes of golde.
sp.l: The grownde whereon it groes, the grasse, the roote of golde,
The body and the bark of golde, all glitteringe to beholde,
The leaues of burnysht golde, the fruites that thereon growe
Are diadems sett with pearle in golde in gorgeous glistringe showe:
And yf this Tree of Golde, in lue may not suffize,
Require a grove of golden trees, so, Iuno beare the prize.

div.stage: The Tree sinketh.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Me lyst not tempt thee with decayinge wealthe,
Which is embaset by want of lusty healthe:
But yf thou haue a minde to fly aboue,
Y crowned with fame neere to the seate of Ioue:
Yf thou aspire to wysdomes worthines.
Whereof thow mayst not see the brightnes
Yf thou desyre honor of chyuallrye,
To bee renouned for happy victorie,
To fighte it out, and in the champaine feilde,
To shrowde thee vnder pallas warlike sheilde,
To praunce on barbed steedes, this honor loe,
My selfe for guerdon shall on thee bestowe.
And for encouragement, that thou mayst see,
What famous knightes dame Pallas warriers be,
Beholde in Pallas honour here they come,
Marching alonge with founde of thundring drom.

div.stage: PALLAS SHOW.
Hereuppon did enter .9. knights in armour, treading a warlike Almaine, by drome and fife, & then hauing march't foorth againe, Venus speaketh.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Come sheepeherde, come, sweete sheepeherde looke on me,
These bene to hoat alarams these for thee:
But if thou wilt giue mee the golden ball,
Cupide my boy shall hate to playe withall,
That when so ere this apple he shall see,
The god of loue himselfe shall thinke on the,
And bid thee looke and chuse, and he will wounde,
Whereso thy fancyes obiect shalbe founde,
And lightlie when he shootes he doth not misse:
And I will giue the many louelie kysse,
And come and play with thee on Ida here,
And if thou wilt a face that hath no peere,
A gallant girle, a lustie minion trull,
That can giue sporte to thee thy bellyfull,
To rauish all thy beating vaines with ioye,
Here is a lasse of Venus court, my boy,
Here gentle sheepeherde, heres for thee a peece,
The fayrest face, the flower of gallant Greece.
sp.stage: Here Helen entreth in her brauerie, with 4. Cupides attending on her, each hauing his fan in his hande to fan fresh ayre in her face. shee singeth as followeth.
sp.l: SI Diana nel cielo è vna stella
Chiara, è lucente piena di splendore
Che porge luc 'all' affanato cuore:
Si Diana, nel ferno è vna dea,
Che deconforto all' anime dannate,
Che per amor son morte desperate:
Si Diana ch' in 〈◊〉 è delle nimphe
Reina, imperatiue di dolce fiori
Tra bosch'e Selue da morte a pastori.
Io son vn Diana dolce e rara
Chle con Le guardi Io posso far guerra
A Dian' infern 'in cielo, et in terra.

div.stage: Exit.
The song being ended Helen departeth, & Paris Speaketh.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Most heauenly dames, was never man as I
Poore shepherde swaine, so happy and vnhappy:
The least of these delights, that you deuyse.
Able to wrape and dazle humaine eyes.
But since my silence may not pardoned bee,
And I appoint which is the fayrest shee,
Pardon, most sacred dames, sythe one not all,
By Paris doome must haue this golden ball.
Thy beautye, stately Iuno, dame deuine,
That lyke to Phoebus golden beames doth shine,
Approues it selfe to bee most excellent,
But that fayre face that dothe me most content,
Sythe fayre, faire dames, is neyther shee nor shee,
But shee whome I shall fairest deeme to bee.
That face is hers that hight the Queene of Loue,
Whose sweetenes dothe bothe gods and creatours moue.
sp.stage: He giueth the golden Ball to venus.
sp.l: And if the fayrest face deserue the ball,
Fayre Venus, Ladyes, beares it from yee all.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And in this ball dothe Venus more delight,
Then in her louely boy faire Cupids sighte.
Come shepherd comme, sweete Venus is thy frend,
No matter how thow other gods offend.

div.stage: Venus taketh paris with her.
Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: But he shall rue, and ban the dismal day
wherein his Venus bare the ball away:
And heauen and earth iust wittnesses shall bee,
I will reuenge it on his progenye.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: well Iuno, whether wee bee leyfe or lothe,
Venus hathe got the aple from vs bothe.

div.stage: Exeunt Ambo

div.head: SCENA. I.
div.stage: Colin thenamored sheepeherd singeth his passion of loue▪

lg.head: The songe.
lg.l: O gentle loue, vngentle for thy deede,
Thou makest my harte
A bloodie marke
With pearcyng shot to bleede.
Shoote softe sweete loue, for feare thou shoote amysse,
For feare too keene.
Thy arrowes beene,
And hit the harte, where my beloued is.
To faire that fortune were, nor neuer I
Shalbe so blest
Among the rest
That loue shall ceaze on her by simpathye.
Then since with loue my prayers beare no boot,
This doth remayne
To cease my payne,
I take the wounde, and dye at Venus foote.

div.stage: Exit Colin.

div.head: ACT. III.
SCENA. II.
div.stage: Hobinol, Digon, Thenot.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Poore Colin wofull man, thy life forespoke by loue,
What vncouth fit, what maladie is this, that thou dost proue.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Or loue is voide of phisicke cleane, or loues our common wracke,
That giues vs bane to bring vs lowe, and let vs medicine lacke.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: That euer loue had reuerence 'mong sillie sheepeherd swaines,
Belike that humor hurtes them most that most might be their paines.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Hobin, it is some other god that cheerisheth her sheepe,
For sure this loue doth nothing else but make our herdmen weepe.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: And what a hap is this I praye, when all our woods reioyce,
For Colin thus to be denyed his yong and louely choice.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She hight in deede so fresh and faire that well it is for thee,
Colin and kinde hath bene thy friende, that Cupid coulde not see.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: And whether wendes you thriueles swaine, like to the striken deere,
Seekes he Dictamum for his wounde within our forrest here.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: He wendes to greete the Queene of loue, that in these woods doth wonne,
With mirthles layes to make complaint to Venus of her sonne.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A Colin thou art all deceiued, shee dalleys with the boy,
And winckes at all his wanton prankes, and thinkes thy loue a toy.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Then leaue him to his luckles loue, let him abide his fate,
The sore is ranckled all to farre, our comforte coms to late.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Though Thestilis the Scorpion be that breakes his sweete assault,
Yet will Rhamnusia vengeance take, on her disdainefull fault.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Lo yonder comes the louely Nymphe, that in these Ida vales,
Playes with Amintas lustie boye, and coyes him in the dales.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thenot, me thinks her cheere is changed, her mirthfull lookes are layd,
She frolicks not: pray god the lad haue not beguilde the mayde.

div.head: ACT. III.
SCENA. III.
div.stage: Oenone entreth with a wreath of popular on her heade. Manent Pastores.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Beguilde, disdayned, and out of loue: liue longe thou Poplar-tree,
And let thy letters growe in length, to witnes this with mee.
A Venus, but for reuerence, vnto thy sacred name,
To steale a sylly maydens loue, I might account it blame.
And if the tales be true I heare, and blushe for to receite,
Thou dost me wrong to leaue the playnes, and dally out of sight.
False Paris, this was not thy vow, when thou and I were one,
To raung & chaung old loue for new: but now those dayes be gone.
But I will finde the goddesse out, that shee thy vow may reade,
And fill these woods with my lamentes, for thy vnhappy deede.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: So faire a face, so foule a thought to harbour in his breast,
Thy hope consum'd, poore Nymphe, thy hap is worse then all the rest.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: A sheepeherdes, you bin full of wiles, & whet your wits on bookes,
And wrap poore maydes with pypes and songes, and sweete alluring lookes.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.l: Mispeake not al, for his amisse, there bin that keepen flocks,
That neuer chose but once, nor yet beguiled loue with mockes.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: False Paris he is none of those, his trothles doble deede,
Will hurte a many sheepeherds else that might go nigh to speede.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Poore Colin, that is ill for thee, that art as true in trust
To thy sweete smerte, as to his Nymphe Paris hath bin vniust.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: A well is she hath Colin wonne, that nill no other loue:
And woo is me, my lucke is lesse, my paynes no pytie mooue.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Farewell faire Nymphe, sith he must heale alone that gaue the wound.
There growes no herbe of such effect vpon dame natures ground.

div.stage: Exeunt Pastores.
Manet Oenone. Mercu. entr. with Vulcans Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Here is a Nymphe that sadlie sittes, and shee belike
Can tell some newes, Pyracmon, of the iolly swaine we seeke.
Dare wage my winges the lasse doth loue, she lookes so bleak & thin,
And tis for anger or for griefe: but I will talke beginne.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Breake out poore harte, & make complaint the mountaine flocks to moue,
What proude repulse & thanckles scorne thou hast receiued of loue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She singeth, sires, be husht awhile.

div.stage: Oenone singeth as shee suts.

lg.l: Melponie, the muse of tragicke songes,
With moornefull tunes in stole of dismall hue,
Assist a sillie Nymphe to wayle her woe,
And leaue thy lustie companie behinde.
Thou luckles wreath, becomes not me to weare
The Poplar tree for triumphe of my loue.
Then as my ioye my pride of loue is lefte,
Be thou vncloathed of thy louelie greene.
And in thy leaues my fortune written bee,
And them some gentle winde let blowe abroade,
That all the worlde may see how false of loue,
False Paris hath to his Oenone bene.

div.stage: The songe ended, Oenone sitting still. Mercurie speaketh.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good-day fayre mayde, werie belike with following of your game,
I wish thee cunning at thy will, to spare or strike the same.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: I thanke you sir, my gaine is quick and rids a length of grounde,
And yet I am deceaued or else a had a deadlie wounde.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your hand perhaps did swarue awarie. Oen. or else it was my harte.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Then sure a plyed his fotemanship.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: a played a raunging parte.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You should haue giuen a deeper wound.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: I could not that for pity.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: You should haue eyd him better than.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: blind loue was not so witty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why tell me sweete, are you in loue.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: or would I were not so.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yee meane because a does ye wrong.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: perdie the more my woe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why meane ye loue, or him ye loued?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: wel may I meane them both.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is loue to blame?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: the queene of loue hath made him false his troth.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: meane ye indeede the queene of loue.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: euen wanton Cupids dame.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why was thy loue so louely then?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: his beautie hight his shame,
The fairest sheepeherde one our greene.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: is he a sheepeherd than.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: And sometime kept a bleating flock.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: enough, this is the man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Where woons he than?

sp.speaker: Oen▪
sp.l: about these woods: far from the Poplar tree.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What Poplar meane ye?

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: witnes of the vowes betwixt him & me.
And come and wend a little way and you shall see his skill.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sirs tarrie you.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: nay let them goe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: nay not vnles you will.
Stay Nymphe, and harke what I say of him thou blamest so,
And credit me, I haue a sad discourse to tell thee ere I go.
Know then, my pretie mops, that I hight Mercurie,
The messenger of heauen, and hether flie
To cease vpon the man whom thou dost loue,
To summon him before my father Ioue,
To answere matter of great consequence,
And Ioue himselfe will not be longe from hence.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: Sweete Mercurie, and haue poore Oenons cryes,
For Paris fault, ypeircest th'unpertiall skyes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The same is he, that iolly sheepeherdes swaine.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: His flocke do graze vpon Auroras plaine,
The colour of his coate is lustie greene,
That would these eyes of mine had neuer seene,
His tycing curled hayre, his front of yvorie,
Then had not I poore I bin vnhappie.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No maruell wench, although we cannot finde him,
When all to late the queene of heauen doth minde him.
But if thou wilt haue physicke for thy sore,
Minde him who list, remember thou him no more:
And find some other game, and get thee gon.
For here will lustie suters come anon,
To hoat and lustie for thy dyeing vaine,
Such as were monte to make their sutes in vaine.

div.stage: Exit Merc. cum Cyclop.

sp.speaker: Oen.
sp.l: I will goe sit and pyne vnder the Poplar tree,
And write my answere to his vow, that euerie eie may see.

div.head: ACT. III.
SCENA V.
div.stage: Venus, Paris, and a companie of sheepeherdes.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Sheepeherdes, I am contente, for this sweete sheepeherdes sake,
A straunge reuenge vpon the maide and her disdaine to take.
Let Colins corps be brought in place, and burned in the plaine,
And let this be the verse. The loue whom Thestilis hath slaine.
And trust me I will chide my sone for parciallitie,
That gaue the swaine so deepe a wound, and let her scape him by.

sp.speaker: Pasto.
sp.l: Alas that euer loue was blinde, to shoote so farre amisse.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Cupid my sonne was more to blame, the fault not mine, but his.

div.stage: Pastores exeunt, Manent. Ven. cum Par.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: O madam, if your selfe would daine the handling of the bowe,
Albeit it be a taske, your selfe more skill, more iustice knowe.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Sweete sheepeherde, didst thou euer loue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Lady, a little once.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And art thou changed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: faire queene of loue I loued not al attonce.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Well wanton, were thou wounded so deepe as some haue ben,
It were a cunning cure to heale and rufull to be seene.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But tell me, gracious goddesse, for a flawe and false offence,
Hath Venus or her sonne the power, at pleasure to dispence.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: My boy, I will instruct thee in a peece of poetrie,
That happly erst thou hast not heard: in hel there is a tree,
Where once a day doe sleepe the soules of false foresweren louers,
With open hartes, and there aboute in swarmes the number houers
Of poore forsaken ghostes, whose winges from of this tree do beare
Round drops of firie Phlegiton to scorch false hartes with heate.
This payne did Venus and her sonne, entreate the prince of hell,
T'impose to such as faithles were, to such as loued them well.
And therefore this, my louely boy, faire Venus doth aduise thee,
Be true and stedfast in thy loue, beware thou doe disguise thee.
For he that makes but loue a iest, when pleaseth him to starte,
Shall feele those firye water drops consume his faithles harte.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is Venus and her sonne so full of iustice and seuerytye.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Pittie it weare that loue shoulde not be lincked with indifferencie.
Howe euer louers can exclaime for harde successe in loue,
Trust me, some more then common cause that painfull hap dothe moue.
And cupids bowe is not alone his triumphe, but his rod,
Nor is he only but a boy: he hight a mighty god.
And they that do him reuerence, haue reason for the same,
His shafts keepe heauen and earth in awe, and shape rewardes for flame.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And hathe he reason to mantayne why Colin died for loue.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Yea reason good I warrant thee, in right it might beehoue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then be the name of Ioue adored, his bowe is full of mighte.
His woundes are all but for desert, his lawes are all but right:
well for this once me lyst apply my speeches to thy sense,
And The stilis shall feele the paine for loues supposed offence.
sp.stage: The shepherds bring in Collins Hearce singing.
sp.l: Welladay Welladay: Poore Colin thow arte going to the grounde.
The loue whome Thestis hathe slaine,
Harde harte, faire face fraughte with disdaine:
Disdaine in loue a deadlie wounde.
Wounde her swete loue so deepe againe,
That shee may feele the dyeng paine
Of this vnhappie shepherds swaine,
And dye for loue as Colin died. is Colin died finis Camaenae.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Shepherdes abyde, let Colins corps bee wittnes of the paine
That Thestilis endures in loue, a plague for her dysdaine.
Beholde the organ of our wrathe, this rusty churle is hee,
She dotes on his yllfavored face, so muche accurst is shee.

div.stage: She singeth an old songe called the woing of Colman.
A foule croked Churle enters, & Thestilis a faire lasse wooeth him. he crabedly refuzeth her, and goethe out of place. She tarieth behinde.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: A poore vnhappy Thestilis, vnpitied is thy paine.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Her fortune not vnlyke to his whome cruell thow hast slaine.

div.stage: Thestilis singeth, & the Shepherds replie.

div.head: The songe.
div.l: The straunge effects of my tormented harte,
Whome cruell loue hathe wofull prisoner caughte,
Whome cruel hate hathe into bondage broughte,
Whome wit no way of safe escape hath taughte,
Enforce me say in wittnes of my smarte,
There is no paine to foule disdaine in hardy sutes of loue.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: There is no paine &c.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: Cruell, farewell. Shep Cruell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: Moste cruell thow, of all that nature framed.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: Moste creull &c.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: To kill thy loue with thy disdaine.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: To kill thy loue with thy disdaine.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: Cruell disdaine soe liue thow named.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: Cruell disdaine &c.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: And let me dye of Iphis paine.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: A life to good for thy disdaine.

sp.speaker: Thest.
sp.l: Sithe this my stars to me allot,
And thow thy loue hast all forgot.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: And thou &c.

div.stage: The shepherds carie out Colin.
The grace of this song is in the Shepherds Ecco to her verse.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now shepherds, bury Colins corps, perfume his herce with flowers,
And write what iustice Venus did amid these woods of yours.
How now, how cheeres my Louely boy, after this dump of loue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Such dumpes, sweete Lady, as bin these are deadly dumpes to proue.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Cease shepherde, these are other nues, after this melancholye.
My minde presumes some tempest toward vpon the speache of Mercurie

div.head: ACT. III.
SCENA. VI.
div.stage: Mercurye with Vulcans Cyclops enter. Manentibus Ven. cum Par.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Faire lady Venus, let me pardoned bee
That haue of longe bin wellbeloued of thee,
Yf as my office bid my selfe first brings
To my sweete Madame these vnwellcome tydings.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What nues, what tydings, gentle Mercurie,
In midest of my delites to troble me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: At Iunoes sute, Pallas assisting her,
Sythe bothe did ioyne in sute to Iupiter,
Action is entred in the court of heauen,
And me, the swyftest of the Planets seauen,
With warant they haue thence despatcht away,
To apprehende and finde the man, they say,
That gaue from them that selfesame ball of golde,
Which I presume I do in place beeholde,
Which man, vnles my markes bee taken wyde,
Is hee that sytts so neere thy gracious wyde.
This beinge so, it rests he go from hence.
Before the gods to answere his offence.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What tale is this, dothe Iuno and her mate
Pursue this shepherde with such deadly hate.
As what was then our generall agrement,
To stande vnto they nil be nowe content.
Let Iuno iet, and Pallas play her parte,
What heere I haue, I woonne it by deserte:
And heauen and earthe shall bothe confounded bee,
Ere wronge in this be donne to him or me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This litle fruite, yf Mercury can spell,
Will sende I feare a world of soules to hell.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What meane these Ciclops, Mercurie, is vulcan waxt so fine,
To sende his chimnysweepers forth, to fetter any friende of mine.
Abashe not shepherd at the thinge, my selfe thy baile wilbe,
He shalbe present at the courte of Ioue I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Venus, gyue me your pledge.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.l: my Cestone, or my fan, or bothe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay this shall serue: your worde to mee as sure as is your othe,
At Dianas bowre, and Lady, yf my witt or pollycie
May profit him for Venus sake, let him make bolde with Mercury.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Sweete Paris, whereon doest thow muse?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The angrye heauens for this fatall iar,
Name me the instrument of dire and deadly war.

div.stage: Explicit. Actus Tertius. Exeunt Venus & Paris.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Vulcan following one of Dianas Nymphes.

sp.speaker: Vulc.
sp.l: Why nymphe, what need ye run so fast? what though but black I be?
I haue more preetie knackes to please, then euerie eye doth see,
And though I goe not so vpright, and though I am a smythe,
To make me gratious you may haue some other thinge therewith.

div.head: ACT. IIII.
SCENA II.
div.stage: Bacchus, Vulcan, Nymphe.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Yee Vulcane, will yee so in deede may turne and tell him, trull,
He hath a mystresse of his owne to take his belly full.

sp.speaker: Vulc.
sp.l: Why sir, if Phoebes dainty nymphes please lustie Vulcans tooth,
Why may not Vulcan treade awry, aswell as Venus dooth?

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Ye shall not taynt your trothe for me: you wot it verie well,
All that be Dians maides are vowed to halter apples in hell.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Ifaith Ifaith, my gentle mops, but I do know a cast,
Leade apes who list, that we would helpe t'unhaltar them as fast.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Fy fy, your skill is wondrous great, had thought the god of wine,
Had tended but his tubbes and grapes, and not ben haulfe so fine.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Gramercie for that quirke, my girle. Bac. Thats one of dainties frumpes.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: I pray sir take't with all amisse, our cunning comes by lumpes.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Sh'ath capt his aunswere in the Q.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: how sayes, a, has shee so?
Aswel as shee that kapt your head to keepe you warme below.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Yea then you will be curst I see. Bac. best let her euen alone.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Yea gentle gods, and finde some other stringe to harpe vpon.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Some other string, agreed Ifayth, some other pretie thing,
Twere shame fayre maydes should idle be, how say you, wil ye sing.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.l: Some roundes or merry roundylaies, we sing no other songes,
Your melancholick noates not to our countrie myrth belonges.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Here comes a crue will helpe vs trimme.

div.head: ACTVS IIII
SCENA III.
div.stage: Mercurie with the Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yea now our taske is done.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Then merry Mercurie more then time, this rounde were well begone.

div.stage: They sing Hey Downe, downe, downe, &c.
The songe done, she windeth a horne in Vulcans care & runneth out.
Manent. Vulc. Bac. Mer. Cyclops.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: A harletrie I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: a peeuish eluish shroe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Haue seene as farre to come as neare, for all her raunging so.
But, Bacchus, time well spent I wot, our sacred father Ioue,
With Phoebus and the god of warre are met in Dians groue.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Then we are here before them yet, but stay the earth doth swell,
God Neptune to, (this hap is good) doth meete the prince of hell.

div.stage: Pluto ascendeth from below in his chaire. Neptune entreth at an other way.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: What iarres are these, that call the gods of heauen and hell beloe.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: It is a worke of wit and toyle to rule a lustie shroe.

div.head: ACT. IIII.
SCENA. IIII.
div.stage: Enter Iupiter, Saturne, Apollo, Mars, Pluto, Neptune, Bacchus, Vulcan, Mer. Iuno, Pallas, Diana, Cyclops.
Iupiter speaketh.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Bring forth the man of Troie that he may heare,
Whereof he is to be araigned here.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Lo where a comes prepared to pleade his case,
vnder conduct of louely Venus grace.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I haue not seene a more alluring boy.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: So beautie hight the wracke of Priams Troy.

div.stage: The gods being set in Dianaes bower: Inno, Pallas, Diana, Venus and Paris stand on sides before them.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Loe sacred Ioue, at Iunoes proude complaynte,
As erst I gaue my pledge to Mercurie,
I bring the man whom he did late attaint,
To aunswere his inditement orderlie:
And craue this grace of this immortall senate,
That yee allowe the man his aduocate.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: That may not be, the lawes of heauen denie,
A man to pleade or answere by atturney.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Pallas, thy doome is all too peremptorie.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: Venus, that fauour is denyed him flatlie,
He is a man and therefore by out lawes,
Him selfe, without his ayd, must plead his cause.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Then bashe not, sheepeherde, in so good a case,
And friendes thou hast as well as foes in place.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Why, Mercurie, why doe yee not indite him.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Softe gentle, Iuno, I pray you do not bite him.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Nay, gods, I troe you are like to haue great silence,
Vnles this parrot be commaunded hence.

sp.speaker: Iou.
sp.l: Venus, forbeare, be still: speake, Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: If Iuno iangle Venus will replie.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Paris, king Priams sonne, thou art araygned of parciallitie,
Of sentence partiall and vniust, for that without indifferencie,
Beyonde desert or merit far, as thine accusers say,
From them, to Lady Venus here, thou gauest the pryze away.
What is thine answere?
sp.stage: Paris oration to the Councell of the gods.
sp.l: Sacred and iust, thou great and dreadfull Ioue,
And you thrise reuerende powers, whom loue nor hate,
May wrest awry, if this to me a man,
This fortune fatall bee, that I must pleade,
For safe excusall of my giltles thought,
The honour more makes my mishap the lesse,
That I a man must pleade before the gods,
Gratious forbearers of the worldes amisse,
For her, whose beautie how it hath enticet,
This heauenly senate may with me auer.
But sith nor that, nor this may doe me boote,
And for my selfe, my selfe must speaker bee,
A mortall man, amidst this heauenlie presence;
Let me not shape a longe defence, to them,
That ben beholders of my giltles thoughtes.
Then for the deede, that I may not denie,
Wherein consists the full of myne offence,
I did vpon commaunde: if then I erde,
I did no more then to a man belong'd.
And if in verdit of their formes deuine,
My dazled eye did swarue or surfet more
On Iunus face, then anie face of theirs:
It was no partiall fault, but fault of his
Belike, whose eysight not so perfect was,
As might decerne the brightnes of toe rest.
And if it were permitted vnto men
(Ye gods) to parle with your secret thoughtes,
There ben that sit vpon that sacred seate,
That woulde with Paris erre in Venus prayse.
But let me cease to speake of errour here:
Sith what my hande, the organ of my harte,
Did giue with good agreement of myne eye,
My tongue is voyde with processe to maintaine.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: A iolly sheepeherde, wise and eloquent.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: First then arraign'de of parciallitie.
Paris replyes vnguiltie of the fact▪
His reason is, because he knewe no more
Faire Venus Ceston, then dame Iunoes mace,
Nor neuer sawe wise Pallas cristall shielde.
Then as I looked I loued and likte attonce,
And as it was referd from them to me,
To giue the pryze to her, whose beautie best
My fancie did commend, so did I prayse
And iudge as might my dazled eye decerne.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: A peece of art, that, cunninglie pardie,
Refers the blame to weakenes of his eye.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Now (for I must adde reason for my deede)
Why Venus rather pleased me of the three:
First, in the intrayles of my mortall eares,
The question standing vpon beauties blaze,
The name of her that height the queene of loue,
My thought in beautie should not be exceld.
Had it bene destyned to maiestie,
(Yet will I not rob Venus of her grace,)
Then stately Iuno might haue borne the ball.
Had it to wisedome bine entituled,
My humaine wit had giuen it Pallas then.
But sith vnto the fayrest of the three,
That power, that threw it for my father ill,
Did dedicate this ball: and safest durst
My sheepeherdes skill aduenture, as I thought,
To iudge of forme and beautie, rather then
Of Iunos state, or Pallas worthynes,
That learnd to ken the fayrest of the flocke,
And praysed beautie but by natures ayme:
Behold to Venus Paris gaue this fruite,
A dayesman chosen there by full consent,
And heauenly powers should not repent their deedes.
Where it is sayde, beyonde desert of hers,
I honoured Venus with this golden prize:
(Yee gods) alas what can a mortall man
Decerne, betwixt the sacred guiftes of heauen.
Or, if I may with reuerence reason thus:
Suppose I gaue, and iudgd corruptly then,
For hope of that, that best did please my thought,
This apple not for beauties prayse alone:
I might offende, sithe I was pardoned,
And tempted, more then euer creature was,
With wealth, with beautie and with chiualrie:
And so preferred beautie before them all,
The thing that hath enchaunted heauen it selfe.
And for the one, contentment is my wealth:
A shell of salte will serue a sheepherde swayne,
A slender banquet in a homely skrip,
And water running from the siluer spring.
For armes, they dreade no foes that sit so lowe,
A thorne can keepe the wind from off my backe,
A sheepe-coate thatcht, a sheepeherdes pallace hight.
Of tragicke Muses sheepeherdes con no skill,
Enough is them, if Cupid ben displeased,
To sing his prayse on slender oten pipe.
And thus, thryse reuerend, haue I tolde my tale,
And craue the torment of my guiltles soule
To be measured by my faultles thought.
If warlicke Pallas, or the queene of heauen
Sue to reuerse my sentence by appeale,
Be it as please your maiesties deuine,
The wronge, the hurte not mine, if anie be,
But hers whose beautie claymed the prize of me.

div.stage: Paris hauing ended, Iupiter speaketh.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Venus, withdrawe your sheepeherde for a space,
Till he againe be called for into place.
Iuno, what will ye after this reply
But doome with sentence of indifferencie.
And if you will but iustice in the cause,
The man must quited be by heauens lawes.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Yea gentle Ioue, when Iunoes sutes are mooued,
Then heauen may see how well shee is beloued.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: But, Madam, fits it maiestie deuine,
In anie sorte from iustice to decline?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Whether the man be guiltie yea or noe,
That doth not hinder our appeale, I troe?

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Phoebus, I wot, amid this heauenly crue,
There be that haue to say as well as you

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: And Iuno, I with them, and they with me,
In lawe and right, must needefully agree:

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I graunt ye may agree, but be content
To doubt vpon regarde of your agrement.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: And if yee markt, the man in his defence.
Saide thereof as a might with reuerence.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: And did yee verie well I promise yee.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: No doubt, sir, you could note it cunninglie.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Well, Iuno, if ye will appeale yee may,
But first dispatch the sheepeherde hence away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then Vulcans dame is like to haue the wronge.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: And that in passion doth to Mars belonge.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Call Venus and the sheepeherde in againe.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: And rid the man that he may knowe his payne.

sp.speaker: Apol.
sp.l: His payne, his payne, his neuer dying payne,
A cause to make to many moe complaine.

div.stage: Mercurie bringeth in Venus and Paris.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Sheepeherd, thou hast ben harde with equitie and law,
And for thy stars do thee to other calling drawe.
We here dismisse thee hence, by order of our senate:
Goe take thy way to Troie, and there abide thy fate.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Sweete shepherde, with such luck in loue while thow dost liue,
As may the Queene of Loue to any Louer giue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My lucke is losse howe ere my loue do speede,
I feare me Paris shall but rue his deede.

sp.speaker: Apo.
sp.l: From Ida woods now wends the shepherds boye,
That in his bosome caries fire to Troy.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Venus, these Ladies do appeale yow see,
And that they may appeale the gods agree,
It resteth then that yow be well content
To stande in this vnto our finall iudgment:
And if king Priams sonne did well in this,
The Lawe of heauen will not leade amysse.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: But, sacred Iupiter, might thy daughter chuse,
Shee might with reason this appeale refuse:
Yet, if they bee vnmoued in their shames,
Bee it a staine and blemysh to their names:
A deede to far vnworthy of the place,
Vnworthy Pallas Launce, or Iunoes mace:
And, if to beauty it bequeathed be,
I doubte not but it will returne to me.

sp.speaker: Pall.
sp.l: Venus, there is no more adoe then soe,
It restethe where the gods doe it bestowe.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: But, Ladies, vnder fauour of your rage,
How ere it be, yow play vppon the vauntage.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Then dames, that wee more freely may debate,
And heere th'indifferent sentence of this senate,
Withdrawe yow from this presence for a space,
Till wee haue thoroughly questioned of the cace:
Dian shalbe your guyde, nor shall yow neede
Your selues t' enquire how things do heere succeede,
Wee will, as wee resolue giue yow to knowe,
By generall doome, how euery thinge doth goe.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Thy will, my wish, faire Ladies, will yee wende?

sp.speaker: Iuno
sp.l: Beshrewe her whome this sentence doth offende.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now Ioue be iust, and gods you that bee Venus freindes,
Yf yow haue ever donne her wronge, then may yow make amends.

div.stage: Manent Dij. Exeunt Diana, Pallas, Iuno, Venus.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: Venus is faire, Pallas and Iuno toe.

sp.speaker: Vulc
sp.l: But tell me now without some more adoe,
Who is the fairest shee, and do not flatter.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Vulcan, vppon comparison hanges all the matter:
That donne the quarrell and the stryfe were ended.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Because tis knowne, the quarrell is pretended.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Mars. you haue reason for your speeche perdie:
My dame (I troe) is fairest in your eye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Or (Vulcan) I shold do her doble wronge.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: About a toy wee tary heere so longe.
Gyue it by voices, voices giue the odds:
A trifle so to to troble all the gods.

sp.speaker: Nep.
sp.l: Beleue me, Saturne, be it so for me.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: For me. Pluto. for me Mars. for me, yf Ioue agre.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And gentle gods, I am indifferent:
But then I knowe whoos's lykely to be shent.

sp.speaker: Ap.
sp.l: Thryse reuerend gods, and thow immortall Ioue.
Yf Phoebus may, as him doth much behoue,
Be licensed, accordinge to our Lawes,
To speake vprightly in this doubted cause,
(Sythe womens witts woorke mens vnceasinge woes)
To make them freindes, that now bin frendles foes,
And peace to keepe with them, with vs, and all
That make their title to this golden ball:
(Nor thincke yee gods my speeche doth derogate
From sacred powre of this immortall senate,)
Refer this sentence where it doth belonge,
In this say I fayre Phoebe hathe the wronge.
Not that (I meane) her beautye beares the prize:
But that the holly Lawe of heauen denies,
One god to medle in an others powre.
And this befell so neere Dianas bowre,
As for thappeazinge this vnplesant grudge,
(In my conceyte) shee hight the fittest iudge.
Yf Ioue comptroll not Plutoes hell with charmes,
Yf Mars haue souraigne powre to manage armes:
Yf Bacchus beare no rule in Neptune sea
Nor Vulcans fire dothe Saturnes sythe obay:
Suppresse not then, 'gainst lawe and equitie,
Dianas power in her owne territorie:
Whose regiment, amid her sacred bowers,
As proper height as anie rule of yours.
Well may we so wipe all the speeche awaie,
That Pallas, Iuno, Venus hath to say,
And aunswere that by iustice of our lawes,
We were not suffred to conclude the cause.
And this to me most egall doome appeares,
A woman to be iudge amonge her pheeres.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Apollo hath founde out the onely meane,
To rid the blame from vs and trouble cleane.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: We are beholding to his sacred wit.

sp.speaker: Iup.
sp.l: I can commend and well allow of it.
And so deriue the matter from vs all,
That Dian haue the giuing of the ball.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: So Ioue may clearly excuse him in the case,
Where Iuno else woulde chide and braule apace.

div.stage: All they rise and goe foorth.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And now, it were some cunnning to deuine,
To whom Diana will this pryze resigne.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Suffizeth me, it shall be none of mine.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.l: Vulcan, though thou be blacke, thart nothing fine.

sp.speaker: Vul.
sp.l: Goe bathe thee, Bacchus, in a tub of wine,
The balls as likely to be mine as thine.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes:

div.head: ACT. V. & vltimi,
SCENA I.
div.stage: Diana, Pallas, Iuno, Venus.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Lo, Ladyes, farre beyonde my hope and will, you see,
This thankles office is imposd to me:
Wherein if you will rest aswell content,
As Dian wilbe iudge indifferent,
My egall doome shall none of you offende,
And of this quarrell make a finall ende:
And therefore, whether you beliefe of loath,
Confirme your promise with some sacred othe.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Phoebe, chiefe Mistresse of this siluan chace,
Whom gods haue chosen to conclude the case,
That yet in ballance vndecyded lies.
Touching bestowing of this golden prize.
I giue my promise and mine othe withall,
By Stix, by heauens power imperiall,
By all that longes to Pallas deytie,
Her shilde, her launce, ensignes of chiuallrie,
Her sacred wreath of Oliue, and of Baye,
Her crested helme, and else what Pallas may,
That where so ere this ball of purest golde,
That chast Diana here in hande doth holde,
Vnpartially her wisedome shall bestowe,
Without mislike or quarrell any moe,
Pallas shall rest content and satisfied,
And say the best desert doth there abide.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: And here I promise and protest withall,
By Stix, by heauens power imperiall,
By all that longes to Iunoes deitie,
Her crowne, her mace, ensignes of maiestie:
Her spotles mariage-rites, her league diuine,
And by that holy name of Proserpine,
That wheresoere, this ball of purest golde,
That chast Diana here in hande doth holde,
Vnpartially her wisedome shall bestowe,
Without mislike or quarrell anie moe,
Iuno shall rest content and satisfied,
And say the best desert doth there abyde.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: And louely Phoebe, for I knowe thy dome
Wilbe no other then shall thee become,
Beholde I take thy daintie hande to kisse,
And with my solemne othe confirme my promise,
By Stix, by Ioues immortall emperie,
By Cupids bowe, by Venus mirtle-tree,
By Vulcans gifte, my Ceston, and my fan,
By this red rose, whose colour first began,
When erst my wanton boy (the more his blame)
Did drawe his bowe awry and hurt his dame,
By all the honour and the sacrifice,
That from Cithaeron and from Paphos rise:
That wheresoere, &c.
Venus shall rest, &c.

div.stage: vt supra.
Diana hauing taken their othes speaketh.
Diana describeth the Nymphe Eliza a figure of the Queene.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: It is enough, and goddesses attende:
There wons within these pleasaunt shady woods,
Where neither storme nor Suns distemperature
Haue power to hurte by cruell heate or colde,
Vnder the clymate of the milder heauen,
Where seldome lights Ioues angrie thunderbolt,
For fauour of that soueraygne earthly peere:
Where whystling windes make musick 'mong the trees,
Far from disturbance of our countrie gods,
Amids the Cypres springes a gratious Nymphe,
That honour Dian for her chastitie,
And likes the labours well of Phoebes groues:
The place Elizium hight, and of the place,
Her name that gouernes there Eliza is,
A kingdome that may well compare with mine.
An auncient seat of kinges, a seconde Troie,
Ycompast rounde with a commodious sea:
Her people are ycleeped Angeli,
Or if I misse a lettre is the most.
She giueth lawes of iustice and of peace,
And on her heade as fits her fortune best,
She weares a wreath of laurell, golde, and palme:
Her robes of purple and of scarlet die,
Her vayle of white, as best befits a mayde.
Her auncestors liue in the house of fame,
Shee giueth armes of happie victorie,
And flowers to decke her lyons crowned with golde.
This peereles nymphe whom heauen and earth beloues,
This Paragon, this onely this is shee,
In whom do meete so manie giftes in one,
On whom our countrie gods so often gaze,
In honour of whose name the Muses singe.
In state Queene Iunos peere, for power in armes,
And vertues of the minde Mineruaes mate,
As fayre and louely as the queen of loue:
As chast as Dian in her chast desires.
The same is shee, if Phoebe doe no wronge,
To whom this ball in merit doth belonge.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: If this be shee whom some Zabeta call,
To whom thy wisedome well bequeathes the ball
I can remember at her day of birthe,
Howe Flora with her flowers strewed the Earth,
How euerie power with heauenlie maiestie,
In person honored that solemnitie.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: The louely graces were not farre away,
They threw their balme for triumph of the day.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The fates against their kinde beganne a cheerefull songe,
And vowed her life with fauour to prolonge
Then first gan Cupids eysight wexen dim,
Belike Elisas beautie blinded him.
To this fayre Nymphe, not earthly but deuine:
Contents it me my honour to resigne.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: To this fayre Queene so beautifull and wise,
Pallas bequeathes her title in the prize.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: To her whom Iunoes lookes so well become,
The queene of heauen yeildes at Phoebus doome.
And glad I am Diana found the arte,
Without offence so well to please desart.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Then marke my tale the vsuall time is nie,
When wont the denies of life and destinie,
In robes of cheerfull collours to repayre,
To this renowned Queene so wise and fayre,
With pleasaunt songes this peereles nimphe to greete,
Clotho layes downe her distaste at her feete.
And Lachesis doth pull the threed at length,
The thirde with fauour giues it stuffe and strength
And for contrarie kinde affordes her leaue,
As her best likes her web of life to weaue
This time we will attend, and in the meane while
With some sweete songe the tediousnes beguile.

div.stage: The Musicke sounde and the Nimphes within singe or solfa with voyces and instrumentes awhile. Then enter Clotho, Lachesis and Atropos singing as followeth: The state being in place.

div.head: The songe.

sp.speaker: Cloth.
sp.l: Humanae vitae filum sic voluere Parcae.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Humanae vitae filum sic tendere Parcae.

sp.speaker: Atrop.
sp.l: Humanae vitae filum sic scindere Parcae.

sp.speaker: Cloth.
sp.l: Clotho colum baiulat.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Lachesis trahit.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Atropos occat.

sp.speaker: Tres simul.
sp.l: Viue diu foelix votis hominúmque deûmque:
Corpore, mente, libro, doctissima, candida, casta.

div.stage: They lay downe their properties at the Queenes feete.

sp.speaker: Cloth.
sp.l: Clotho colum pedibus.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.l: Lachesis tibi pendula fila.

sp.speaker: Atr.
sp.l: Et fatale tuis manibus ferrum Atropos offert.
Viue diu foelix, &c.

div.stage: The song being ended Clotho speakes to the Queene.

sp.speaker: Cloth.
sp.l: Gracious and wise, fayre Queene of rare renowne,
Whom heauen and earth beloues amyd thy trayne,
Noble and louely peeres: to honour thee
And doe thee fauour, more then may belong,
By natures lawe to any earthly wight,
Beholde continuance of our yearely due,
Th'unpartiall dames of destenie we meete,
As haue the gods and we agreed in one,
In reuerence of Elizas noble name,
And humblie loe her distaffe Clotho yeeldes.

lg.l: Her spindle Lachesis and her fatall reele,
Layes downe in reuerence at Elizas feete.
Te tamen in terris vnam tria numina Diuam
Inuita statuunt naturae lege sorores,
Et tibi non alijs didicerunt parcere Parcae.

sp.speaker: Atro.
sp.l: Dame Atrops according as her 〈◊〉
To thee fayre Queene resignes her fatall knife:
Liue longe the noble Phoenix of our age,
Our fayre Eliza our Zabeta fayre.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: And loe beside this rare solemnitie,
And sacrifice these dames are wont to doe,
A fauour far in deed contrarie kinde,
Bequeathed is vnto thy worthynes.
Shee deliuereth the ball of golde to the Queenes owne hands
This prize from heauen and heauenly goddesses,
Accept it then, thy due by Dians dome,
Praise of the wisedome, beautie and the state,
That best becomes thy peereles excellencie.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: So fayre Eliza, Venus doth resigne,
The honour of this honour to be thine.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: So is the queene of heauen content likewise,
To yelde to thee her title in the prize.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: So Pallas yeeldes the prayse hereof to thee▪
For wisedome, princely state, and peerelesse beautie.

div.head: EPILOGVS.
div.stage: Omnes simul.
div.l: Viue diu foelix votis hominúmque Deûmque.
Corpore, mente, libro, doctissima, candida, casta.
div.stage: Exeunt omnes.
